Im a beginner programmer, and I’m making a code for a PID-controlled elevator with 4 buttons, one for each setpoint, but the code isn’t working, any help? I’m using a NEO Vortex with a spark flex.

Here the code

Need pid.setSetpoint(setpoint) in the setSetpoint method.

Also don’t setPID values in periodic()

Read this plus search this forum for elevator. There are several this season.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

PID Control in WPILib

WPILib supports PID control of mechanisms through the PIDController class ( Java, C++, Python). This class handles the feedback loop calculation for the user, as well as offering methods for return...

What didn’t work?
What did you try?
Why are you using a separate encoder than the one that is included in the SparkMax?
Explain the distance per pulse of (Math.PI * 1.5) / 360.0
When you lift the elevator by hand, does “Altura Atual” follow the movement?

I wrote this earlier this season, it sounds relevant to your problem:

Elevator speed Programming
Always try to isolate the cause; reduce the number of possible culprits. If closed-loop control isn’t working, make sure it works under raw human control. There’s an order to do things for a closed-loop system, stopping if something doesn’t work properly. Here’s what I recommend for an elevator: mechanics: (as Practicality says above); does it move easily and smoothly? Is there an absence of bad sounds? If not, try to isolate the problem; check with the power on and off, to verify that it…

The short of it is, if something isn’t right after steps 1 thru 9, it’s not only going to mess up step 10, but it’s going to be hard to figure out when you went wrong. Check things in order and you’ll have a better time.

In general, questions for troubleshooting are best asked in the form of:

"I did X and I expected Y to happen, but Z happened instead; how do I get Y to happen?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-26T20:32:05.724Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":94,"readers_count":93,"score":28.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":493311,"topic_slug":"elevator-not-working","display_username":"usbcd36","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/elevator-speed/482750/6","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Elevator speed","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7334,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevator-not-working/493311/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3541854,"name":"João Victor","username":"jvsinho","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/b5e925/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T21:06:47.002Z","cooked":"

The values ​​on the Shuffleboard are not appearing (the values are aways 0.0), and in addition, the engine is not running, including the four levels that I configured. Regarding the encoder, I am using what is already integrated into Spark Flex (or at least I think so). I read the documentation for the REV and WPILib libraries and, from what I understand, this is the correct way to use an encoder. However, I have no experience with encoders other than those we use to move the swerve.

To test, I tried turning on and moving the motor waiting for the values ​​on the Shuffleboard to update, but nothing changed.

The line of code:

m_encoder.setDistancePerPulse(1.0 / 360.0 * 2.0 * Math.PI * 1.5);

basically converts the encoder pulses into actual distance traveled (in my case, in meters). However, I’m not sure if I’ve configured this correctly or if there is some other issue preventing the values ​​from updating.

I didn’t write this code 100% for myself, so I’m not sure I understand completely either.

Looking at the tips you gave me, I think my main issue is my limited knowledge of WPILib programming. I feel like my code is missing some values or calculations, but I’m not sure how to implement them properly. I understand the concepts, but actually writing the code and making everything work is where I get stuck. I even tried looking at other elevator models but it didn’t help much. Any tips on what I could implement in the code, or if it’s missing something?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-26T21:25:18.326Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":57,"readers_count":56,"score":11.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":493311,"topic_slug":"elevator-not-working","display_username":"João Victor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":7334,"username":"usbcd36","name":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73509,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-not-working/493311/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3541883,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T21:33:17.749Z","cooked":"
jvsinho:

The values ​​on the Shuffleboard are not appearing

Probably best to get the Shuffleboard stuff working properly. Line 57 looks correct to me; you should get an “Altura Atual” box in Shuffleboard from it.

Do you get any boxes with numbers (even wrong/zero numbers), or no boxes at all?

jvsinho:

I am using what is already integrated into Spark Flex (or at least I think so).

The class Encoder (edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Encoder) reads an encoder connected to digital inputs on the roboRIO. If you want to read the SPARK FLEX’s encoder, you’ll need to call some methods on your motor object instead to read its connected encoder instead. I don’t know exactly what these are, but the REVLib docs are probably the place to start.

jvsinho:

The line of code:

m_encoder.setDistancePerPulse(1.0 / 360.0 * 2.0 * Math.PI * 1.5);

Part of the reason (I think) icemannie called this out is because it looks like a number with units radians/degree * something. However, the method name is setDistancePerPulse, and it takes in an argument in output units per encoder pulse, which is neither of the above. However, I don’t think it’s worth getting into because I don’t think the SPARK FLEX encoder stuff has that capability, and I don’t know what units it comes out as anyway – probably rotations, though. As a result, you’ll probably need to do a manual conversion, but I would leave that until after you can read the position out in raw units and see it on the dashboard.

Also, Glass has better plotting than Shuffleboard. If you’re already experienced with Shuffleboard, stick with it. Otherwise, try out Glass.

I don’t have much experience with Shuffleboard, so I’ll try using ‘Glass’. As for the values, they appear in the boxes, but are always 0.0. Another thing, would you recommend working on the ‘Elevator’ or ‘ElevatorTest’ class? The ‘ElevatorTest’ class was not created by me, so I don’t quite understand how it works. Which do you think would be best for the elevator in terms of functionality?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-26T21:46:14.993Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":38,"readers_count":37,"score":17.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":493311,"topic_slug":"elevator-not-working","display_username":"João Victor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":7334,"username":"usbcd36","name":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73509,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-not-working/493311/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3541899,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T21:58:30.328Z","cooked":"

Looks like both of them are using the same Encoder class, which I think is the biggest issue right now.

I went poking around in the code you posted (both in the first post and later), and in the first one, ElevadorTESTE.java looks the most promising.

Line 41 reads encoder = motor.getEncoder();, where motor is of type SparkMax. While you would certainly need to modify the code to make it a SPARK FLEX, the fact that it’s calling a method getEncoder on the motor controller object is promising.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-26T21:58:30.328Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":34,"readers_count":33,"score":16.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":493311,"topic_slug":"elevator-not-working","display_username":"usbcd36","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":73509,"username":"jvsinho","name":"João Victor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/b5e925/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7334,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevator-not-working/493311/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3541927,"name":"icemannie","username":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T22:31:00.377Z","cooked":"

Start simple using this code to just run the elevator up and down.

public class Elevator extends SubsystemBase {
private final SparkFlex elevatorMotor = new SparkFlex(11, MotorType.kBrushless);
public final RelativeEncoder elevatorEncoder = elevatorMotor.getEncoder();

public Elevator() {

}

@Override
public void periodic() {
    // Display sensor readings to ShuffleBoard
    SmartDashboard.putNumber("Elevator Position", elevatorEncoder.getPosition());
    SmartDashboard.putNumber("Elevator Velocity1", elevatorEncoder.getVelocity());
}

// This function sets the motor to one adjustable speed
public void setElevatorMotor(double speed) {
    elevatorMotor.set(speed);
}

public Command runElevator(double speed) {
    return Commands.runOnce(() -> setElevatorMotor(speed));
}

public Command stopElevator() {
    return Commands.runOnce(() -> elevatorMotor.stopMotor());
}

}

Then in Robot Container add this

controleXbox.rightTrigger.whileHeld((elevatorSubsystem.runElevator(.5))
.onFalse(elevatorSubsystem.stopElevator());

controleXbox.leftTrigger.whileHeld((elevatorSubsystem.runElevator(-.5))
.onFalse(elevatorSubsystem.stopElevator());

These should let you run the elevator up and down at 1/2 speed.
Make sure Shuffleboard is showing the elevator position and speed
Move the elevator 1 meter and note how much elevator position reading changes. This will be the number of motor turns it takes to move the elevator 1 meter.
You can check this number with the mechanics of the elevator.
We can go further when you have this number.
